Sure.  There are several ways to accomplish this.  One way is to install a live image of another OS on your computer.  In this case you want to install a Linux distribution.  A better way would be to purchase a USB drive which contains an Ubuntu or Fedora Linux distro.  Once you have a live image installed on your system you can use a tool such as dd to copy your computer's files from your local drive to the disk image.  The following steps illustrate how to use dd:

sudo dd if=/dev/sdc of=/media/ubuntu.iso.img 
sudo dd if=/dev/sdc of=/media/fedora.iso.img 
sudo dd if=/dev/sdc of=/media/debian.iso.img 
sudo dd if=/dev/sdc of=/media/lubuntu.iso.img 

Or you can just use the Linux command line:

sudo dd if=/dev/sdc of=/media/ubuntu.iso.img 
sudo dd if=/dev/sdc of=/media/fedora.iso.img 
sudo dd if=/dev/sdc of=/media/debian.iso.img

results.raw_gpt4_response:
